title: Philip’s Ministry and the Ethiopian Eunuch
shortSummary: Acts 8 recounts the scattering of the early church due to persecution, leading to the spread of the gospel beyond Jerusalem. Philip’s evangelistic work in Samaria and his encounter with the Ethiopian eunuch demonstrate the expanding reach of the gospel to diverse peoples, emphasizing the power of the Holy Spirit and the necessity of faith and repentance.
timeline: c. AD 33-35 - Early Church Persecution and Expansion

keyCharacters.name: Saul
keyCharacters.description: A fierce persecutor of the early church who consents to Stephen’s death and drives believers from Jerusalem.

keyCharacters.name: Philip
keyCharacters.description: One of the seven deacons who preaches the gospel in Samaria and leads the Ethiopian eunuch to faith and baptism.

keyCharacters.name: Simon the Sorcerer
keyCharacters.description: A magician in Samaria who believes and is baptized but misunderstands the nature of God’s gift, seeking to buy the power of the Holy Spirit.

keyCharacters.name: Ethiopian Eunuch
keyCharacters.description: A high official under Queen Candace who is converted through Philip’s teaching and baptized, symbolizing the gospel’s reach to the Gentiles.

keyCharacters.name: Peter and John
keyCharacters.description: Apostles sent from Jerusalem to pray for new Samaritan believers to receive the Holy Spirit.

definitions.definition: The practice of magic or witchcraft, often associated with deception and false power, as seen in Simon’s previous activities.
The third Person of the Trinity, God’s Spirit who empowers, guides, and sanctifies believers.
A Christian ordinance symbolizing repentance, faith in Christ, and entrance into the community of believers.
A castrated man often serving in royal courts, here representing a Gentile seeking God.

outline.heading: Persecution and Scattering of the Church
outline.description: Following Stephen’s martyrdom, Saul’s persecution causes believers to scatter from Jerusalem, fulfilling Jesus’ command to witness beyond the city.

outline.heading: Philip’s Ministry in Samaria
outline.description: Philip preaches Christ in Samaria, performing miracles and converting many, including Simon the sorcerer, highlighting the gospel’s power and the necessity of genuine faith.

outline.heading: The Holy Spirit Given to Samaritan Believers
outline.description: Peter and John pray for the Samaritan converts to receive the Holy Spirit, demonstrating the unity of the church and the Spirit’s role in salvation.

outline.heading: Simon’s Rebuke and Call to Repentance
outline.description: Simon’s attempt to buy the Spirit’s power is sternly rebuked by Peter, emphasizing that God’s gifts cannot be purchased and calling Simon to repentance.

outline.heading: Philip and the Ethiopian Eunuch
outline.description: Directed by an angel and the Spirit, Philip explains Isaiah’s prophecy to the eunuch, leading to his faith and baptism, symbolizing the gospel’s outreach to the nations.

application: Trust God’s sovereign plan even in times of persecution, knowing He uses hardship to spread the gospel.
Seek to share the gospel boldly and rely on the Holy Spirit’s power rather than human wisdom or manipulation.
Examine your heart for selfish motives in ministry and be willing to repent and seek God’s forgiveness.
Be attentive to God’s guidance through prayer and Scripture to reach those who are seeking the truth.

keyVerses.text: Therefore they that were scattered abroad went every where preaching the word.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights how persecution led to the gospel’s expansion, fulfilling Jesus’ command to be witnesses beyond Jerusalem.

keyVerses.text: But Peter said unto him, Thy money perish with thee, because thou hast thought that the gift of God may be purchased with money.
keyVerses.significance: Peter’s rebuke to Simon underscores that salvation and spiritual gifts are freely given by God and cannot be bought.

keyVerses.text: And Philip said, If thou believest with all thine heart, thou mayest. And he answered and said, I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God.
keyVerses.significance: This confession of faith is essential for baptism and salvation, emphasizing wholehearted belief in Jesus as the Son of God.

keyVerses.text: And when they were come up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord caught away Philip, that the eunuch saw him no more: and he went on his way rejoicing.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the joy and empowerment that come from salvation and the Spirit’s active work in the believer’s life.
